title: Baseball Great Barry Larkin Takes Another Swing at Selling Orlando Mansion
text:
Baseball Hall of Famer Barry Larkin and his wife Lisa Larkin are relisting their Orlando, Fla.-area home for $5.4 million, or roughly half of what they sought when they first put it on the market seven years ago.

The problem: The home, built to suit to their tastes, isn’t for everyone. “It’s going to take a specific buyer to see what we have here,” Mr. Larkin said.

The Bright and Shiny Home of Baseball’s Barry Larkin Outside Orlando, Fla., the custom-built mansion speaks to the family’s bold style.

In the affluent gated community of Windermere, the 14,477-square-foot lakefront property has a two-story entry foyer with twin glass staircases, a domed ceiling, double aquariums and a massive star-shaped tile mosaic on the floor. After a brief flirtation with banana yellow, the couple opted for glossy electric blue cabinetry in the kitchen. More recently, they turned a former baseball conditioning room into a nightclub with a DJ booth for their children. Daughter Cymber Larkin, now a recording artist, once threw a Grammy Awards-themed party for friends there, they said.

The furnishings are bold and bright. A movie theater off the kitchen has purple carpeting and red, blue and purple columns.

The seven-bedroom home also has a game room, a gym, a professional recording studio and a two-story glass window overlooking an outdoor pool. Outside, there is a sports court that is used for tennis or basketball and a covered boat dock.

Barry Larkin. Photo: Hans Pennink/Associated Press

The couple built the home in the 1990s after Mr. Larkin, on a fishing break from spring training, spotted an empty lot. They spent several years building the home and raised their three children there, with Mr. Larkin splitting his time between Florida and the Cincinnati area, where he played for the Cincinnati Reds.

“I didn’t want to raise my kids in Cincinnati because I didn’t want them to grow up with the pressures of being the son or daughter of a prominent sports figure in the town,” Mr. Larkin said. The Larkins said they’ve never been uptight about the house, and designed it to be open plan so that their children could run around freely. They even allowed them to skateboard through it.

The couple began marketing the home for sale for $10.9 million in 2012, once their children had mostly grown up. (Their youngest is now 22.) It has undergone several price cuts since then, and was most recently taken off the market in September 2018, priced at $5.9 million. The couple plan to move to a smaller home in South Florida.

Mr. Larkin played shortstop for the Cincinnati Reds from 1986 to 2004 and later served as an analyst for ESPN. He was elected to the National Baseball Hall of Fame in 2012.

Mark Santolin of Engel & Völkers Orlando Winter Park has the listing.

Write to Katherine Clarke at katherine.clarke@wsj.com
description: The former Cincinnati Reds shortstop is relisting his eccentric Windermere home for $5.4 million.
